race.name: Chequamegon MTB
race.tagline: The Cheqâ€”40 years of mass start MTB chaos, 3,000+ riders, and Life Time Grand Prix glory in Wisconsin's Chequamegon National Forest.

vitals.field_size: 3,000+ riders (one of largest MTB races in USA)

terrain.primary: Chequamegon National Forestâ€”MTB singletrack + forest roads
terrain.surface: 60% forest roads, 40% singletrack. Technical MTB terrainâ€”roots, rocks, tight trails. Fire Tower Road climb (mile 10-15). OO section (mile 25-30) legendary technical singletrack. Technical rating: 4/5. MTB skills required.

biased_opinion.summary: Chequamegon MTB is legendaryâ€”40+ years (founded 1983), 3,000+ riders, mass start chaos. Life Time Grand Prix race (pro field: Keegan Swenson, Payson McElveen). 40 miles, 4,000 ft. 60% forest roads, 40% singletrack. Technical MTB terrainâ€”roots, rocks, OO section legendary. Cable small Wisconsin town. Mid-September fall conditions (50-70Â°F). If you want MTB history, mass start chaos, and LTGP glory, this is it. If you want gravel or dropbar, skip it. MTB required.
strengths: Life Time Grand Prix raceâ€”pro field
One of largest MTB races in USA
weaknesses: Mass start bottlenecks (3,000 riders â†’ singletrack)
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Chequamegon MTB is legendary. 40 years, 3,000+ riders, mass start chaos, LTGP race. If you want MTB history and technical terrain, this is bucket-list. If you want gravel or dropbar, skip it. MTB skills required. Mass start is insane. OO section is technical. Come prepared.

logistics.lodging_note: Cable small townâ€”limited lodging. Hayward area also. Book early.
logistics.travel_summary: MSP airport 140 miles. Rental car needed. Cable small town limited lodgingâ€”book early. Friday packet pickup, Saturday race.
logistics.food_options: Aid stations on course. Post-race party in Cable area.
logistics.camping:
campgrounds within an hour
- Hayward KOA: 300ft waterslide, heated pool, mini golf
- Primitive camping along Namekagon River (Nation

course_description.character: 40 miles, 4,000 ft. 60% forest roads, 40% singletrack. Technical MTB terrain. Mass start chaos. Technical rating: 4/5.

suffering_zones.name: Mile 0-5: Mass Start Chaos
suffering_zones.description: 3,000 riders mass start. Bottleneck into forest roads. Start fast or get stuck.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Start position critical. Fast start. Aggressive first miles. Get ahead of traffic.

suffering_zones.name: Mile 10-15: Fire Tower Road Climb
suffering_zones.description: Long forest road climb. Traffic jam if stuck behind slower riders.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Pace conservatively. Pass where possible. Long climb.

suffering_zones.name: Mile 25-30: OO (Double O) Section
suffering_zones.description: Legendary technical singletrack. Roots, rocks, tight trails. Crashes.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: MTB skills critical. Pick lines. Brake early. Technical.

course_description.signature_challenge: Mass start chaos (3,000 riders) + OO section technical singletrack.

history.origin_story: Chequamegon MTB founded 1983. 40+ year history. One of oldest and largest MTB races in USA. 3,000+ riders. Cable Wisconsin. Chequamegon National Forest. Mass start chaos. Life Time Grand Prix race since 2021.
notable_moments: 1983: Foundedâ€”one of oldest MTB races in USA
2021: Added to Life Time Grand Prix series
history.reputation: Legendary MTB. 40+ years. Mass start chaos. LTGP race. Technical terrain.

logistics.explanation: Jenna Rinehart notes this was 'the first time they started the women's field separately from the men,' highlighting how organizers adjust logistics but create new complications. The lottery system requiring March 15 entry and six-month Life Time memberships for priority access remains unnecessarily complex. Point-to-point logistics mean dealing with shuttles between Hayward and Cable, though 43 years of experience shows in race execution.

length.explanation: The race is characterized as 'one long all-out effort for the entire 40 miles' rather than a distance challenge. Elite women like Rinehart and Rollins work together for the first half before separating, while the constant rollers mean leaders finish in roughly two hours. For riders seeking endurance challenges, this feels more like an extended criterium. More compact than Grinduro. As Alexey Vermeulen puts it: "I started trying to make my moves with around seven miles to go. I could see the group was splintering, and guys were chasing to regain contact, and I knew the rubber band would eventually snap and ga..."

technicality.explanation: The course contains 'NO technical singletrack whatsoever' but scores maximum for tactical complexity with 2,100 riders funneling through narrow sections. Rinehart's crash came when her 'front tire slipped out on a rut' with 1.5 miles remaining, while Hall suffered a flat when a 'sharp rock slashed a gaping hole in sidewall.' The Birkie Trail's width creates bottlenecks that end races instantly. Among the most technical in gravel, on par with Badlands. As Ruth Holcomb puts it: "At almost every other race, you climb up a big hill, then you go down the descent and you get to rest down the descent. While the hill is hard, you get full recovery."

elevation.explanation: Rinehart's strategy reveals the elevation challenge: 'I rode at a firm effort knowing that while Fire Tower is hard the race gets even harder when you hit the Birkie trail after that.' The course delivers 61.4 feet of climbing per mile through 'constant punchy rollers' and 'leg burning rollers near the end.' Fire Tower at mile 25-30 is where 'the race blows up' according to multiple elite riders. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds. As Ruth Holcomb puts it: "At almost every other race, you climb up a big hill, then you go down the descent and you get to rest down the descent. While the hill is hard, you get full recovery."

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 70Â°F and lows of 54Â°F, with a 40% chance of rain on any given day. September weather creates equipment gambles, as Hall discovered when a sharp rock punctured his tire during prime racing conditions. Richards called September 'one of the best ever' with perfect temps and moisture, but the month averages 31% chance of rain. When conditions turn, the wide Birkie Trail becomes treacherous enough to cause crashes in the final miles. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Cable, Wisconsin sits at minimal elevation with zero physiological challenge from thin air. The only elevation mentions in rider reports refer to climbing effort, not altitude adaptation. This is pure Midwest terrain offering no acclimatization benefit or altitude training value. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds â€” no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The point-to-point route travels through Chequamegon National Forest on trails accessible only race day, creating exclusivity beyond typical loop courses. The course follows the American Birkebeiner Ski Trail through 'fast flowing and wide grassy cuts through the forest' before hitting forest roads and snowmobile routes. Fall conditions and Northwoods terrain provide adventure backdrop, though the wide trail prevents backcountry isolation.

prestige.explanation: Elite riders like Vermeulen treat this as a marquee win, with his 2025 victory marking his third Chequamegon title. Rinehart's comment about her '11th Chequamegon race' shows how veterans return year after year. The Life Time Grand Prix Series integration means top cyclists like Rollins and Olshove line up in Cable, while the lottery system exists because demand crushes supply among serious racers.

race_quality.explanation: Vermeulen's tactical awarenessâ€”'I could see the group was splintering, and guys were chasing to regain contact, and I knew the rubber band would eventually snap'â€”shows the race rewards strategic racing despite the power focus. The 2025 course change separating pro and mass fields 'allowed for additional space with passing' while maintaining competitive integrity through technical final sections.

experience.explanation: The race creates memorable moments from start to finish, with Rinehart's crash 1.5 miles from the line epitomizing the drama: 'I got back up as quickly as possible but was feeling discouraged...I started to pedal a bit more and rounded a corner and realized I could still see Melisa up ahead.' The point-to-point journey from downtown Hayward through national forest to Telemark Resort delivers a complete racing narrative.

community.explanation: The event creates 'a full-on celebration of mountain biking' where 'Hayward and Cable rally around the event with cheering crowds and strong volunteer presence.' Starting at 10am means 'riders come in hot in a short time frame and the party escalates quickly.' The festival atmosphere includes music, expo, and vendors, while organizers maintain family focus with free Little Loggers races. As Pirates and Fun puts it: "The party in the Northwoods saw pirates offering rum hand-ups on the trails, contributing to the atmosphere."

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 3,000+ riders (one of largest MTB races in USA), rollins noted staying patient with 'a pretty big group coming through the first feed zone' before the race exploded at Fire Tower, while Hall described 'a large pack the first half of the race' among elite riders. Vermeulen's winning move came from recognizing when 'anybody who got on my wheel wasn't willing to work,' showing depth that creates tactical complexity even on the Birkie Trail. Elite-level competition, on par with Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Melisa Rollins puts it: "We were a pretty big group coming through the first feed zone and I tried to stay patient. The race blew up at mile 25 on the Firetower climb and I was feeling really good."

value.explanation: The $120 entry provides access to exclusive terrain and a festival experience that includes live music, expo, and vendors at the Great Hall finish. Free Little Loggers races show family commitment beyond profit extraction. The lottery system exists because the experience delivers value that creates overwhelming demand among the mountain bike community.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $100-$150. Cable and Hayward require resort-area lodging during peak fall foliage season, with accommodations booking months in advance. The point-to-point format requires shuttle logistics or two-car coordination that loop races avoid. However, Wisconsin pricing beats European race destinations, and the Northwoods offers value compared to mountain town resort pricing during race weekend. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

final_verdict.one_liner: Forty miles of Northwoods power suffering disguised as a mountain bike race that somehow became a gravel institution.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Show up fit or don't show up at allâ€”the Seeley Fire Tower climb doesn't care about your weekend warrior training plan. You need sustained power for constant rollers and the mental fortitude to handle September weather that swings from dust storms to mud festivals. If you can hold 250+ watts for three hours while navigating lottery systems and tourist crowds, this delivers old-school racing credibility.
final_verdict.alternatives: Dirty Kanza (Unbound) gives you similar distance with more predictable suffering and better logistics. For that vintage MTB festival vibe without the Midwest tourist trap energy, try Trans-Sylvania Epic's individual stages.

primary.name: Maxxis Reaver
primary.why: Technical all-rounder. EXO+ casing shrugs off rocks and roots.

videos.title: 2025 Life Time Chequamegon MTB Festival Race Highlights
videos.description:
Catch the race highlights from the 2025 Life Time Grand Prixâ€™s fourth stop â€” the iconic Life Time Chequamegon MTB Festival.

Follow along for an all-out drag race through the Northwoods from Hayward to Cable, WI. The womenâ€™s field reshaped the Grand Prix standings, the menâ€™s race came down to the wire.

ðŸŽ¥ Watch now and follow the action as the 2025 Life Time Grand Prix continues.

Official podium jersey presented by Pas Normal Studios.

Learn more about the Life Time Grand Prix: lifetimegrandprix.com
Learn more about the Chequamegon MTB Festival: cheqmtb.com
videos.transcript:
[Music]
In the heart of northern Wisconsin,
between the small towns of Cable and
Hayward, the woods come alive.
This is the Lifetime Schwamagan Mountain
Bike Festival, where history, grit, and
community all meet on two wheels.
>> I am Cindy Smith Kener. I live right
here in Hayward, Wisconsin. I did my
first Schwamagan 40 in 1984 cuz somebody
told me it would be the hardest thing I
ever did. So I said, "Sign me up." When
it becomes this time of year where the
leaves are turning, you smell the
forest, you can smell the earth, you're
just flying through those hilly grassy
areas, and you're just loving life cuz
it's fall and you get to spend a lot of
time out there. Since 1983, riders have
gathered here to take on the rolling
trails of the Schwamagan National
Forest. What began with 27 cyclists has
grown into one of the most celebrated
off-road races in the country. A true
Midwest Classic that has welcomed
legends, rising stars, and thousands of
everyday riders chasing their very own
finish line.
>> I'm Tim Lewis. Uh, I'm from Phoenix,
Arizona, but I come to cable every
summer of my entire life. And I think
I've done this event 30 times. Cable is
really all about community. And Gary
Krannle way back in the day, whatever,
42 years ago, decided to to start this
event. And it really did build a
community around it. I mean, uh, he had
an amazing group of volunteers,
uh, you know, with Steve Tilford being
part of the first race and, yeah, I
mean, cable's all about community, you
know, everybody's into the the pizza
shop and, uh, Tilly's Trudy at Tilly's
getting pies and and this race just sort
of brings everybody together like some
of the other events here in in cable
between the lakes and the woods and the
trails and um, it's just a magical
place.
[Applause]
>> Yeah, it's pretty cool. And first time
at Schwaming, I remember coming out to
the kids race and it was like 250 kids.
I think this year is almost almost 350.
So, it's just special. It's an easy way
to kind of forget the uh the stress of
the race tomorrow and kind of enjoy a
nice evening. It's not even raining yet.
Welcome to Hayward, Wisconsin, and stop
number four of the 2025 Lif Lifetime
Grand Prix. This is the Schwamagan 40.
Affectionately known as the drag race
from Hayward to Cable. It's 40 mi of
grit, glory, and full gas racing. While
it's the shortest event in the Grand
Prix calendar, make no mistake, it is
absolutely packed with action.
Here we go. the map of the Schwamagan 40
bike race, affectionately known as the
drag race from Hayward, Wisconsin up to
Cable, Wisconsin. The racers start out
with a grassy climb, which everyone
loves to hate, into the single track.
It's all about getting that hole shot
and essentially then everybody starts to
settle down. There are some gravel roads
that cross over the Berky Bonner course
opens up just a little bit before they
head on to our first aid station of the
day, double O. After double O, they're
treated to a little bit of a reprieve
and then the action starts at the top of
the climb. So, you have the highest
point in the course, Fire Tower Hill,
and then followed by the Seven Sisters
after this punchy, brutal climb. After
that climb, there's still nothing left
but pedaling and more undulations. And
really after this uh Timberland trail,
the finish starts to open up. The single
track stops and then we head into power
line. The undulations of power line wide
open, power laid towards the finish. And
here's the hero's welcome.
>> And this year, the pro fields are
stacked. On the women's side, we have
current overall series leader Cesaly
Decker in town as well as last year's
winner Sophia Gomez Vafany.
It's just two points down in the
overall. Well, there's no doubt Vafany
will not only be aiming for the repeat
win, but also the opportunity to move
back into the top overall spot that
she's been so accustomed to. Misa
Rollins is also with us up here in the
Northwoods. Currently sitting third
overall, she's no stranger to success,
having stood on top of the podium back
in 2021.
She's also riding a big wave of
confidence after being the highest
placed lifetime Grand Prix athlete at
the lifetime Leadville Trail 100
mountain bike presented by Kinetic.
On the men's side, well, there's no
doubt that Keegan Swinson will have the
biggest bullseye on his back. In the
midst of an unparalleled run of form,
he's won his fifth straight lifetime
Leadville Trail 100 mountain bike
presented by Kinetic and was most
recently crowned the UCI Cross Country
Marathon World Champion. He's also the
defending champion here and will surely
be looking to carry that form to a
repeat victory.
Just seven points down in second, we
have the Swiss superstar Simone Pow
making his Schwamagan debut. And he will
no doubt keep Keegan on his toes. Don't
forget, we also have last year's runner
up in that tight sprint finish to the
line, Alex Wild looking to avenge that
loss.
The crowds are ready, the athletes are
ready. This is Schwamagan.
All right, and we are off and racing.
Everyone clipped in. We even have some
drop bars here today. Alexis Scarda
basically leading it out the gate.
Melissa Rollins sitting right there.
Second wheel Cesley Decker making sure
that she is moving up, getting good
position.
Women have absolutely gone out on course
with a tear and we are going to be
entitled to the men doing the same
thing. This hill is no joke. It is
beyond steep. The powers and clipping
into the chain rings that we're going to
see behind are astronomical. It's like
they have a second wind coming at us. So
they are humming up this hill making it
look absolutely easy off the start.
All right, we have a quick race update.
Right here at mile 15, we have Sophia
Gomez Vafany leading a group of 10
through headed towards 008 aid station.
And quickly followed on her wheel is
Alexis Garta, Melissa Rollins, Samara
Shepard also rounding out those top
four. And let's not forget we have
Cesaly Decker in here and Cecil Leune,
one of our newcomers to the Lifetime
Grand Prix.
Race update from mile 15. Keegan Swinson
up front. Brendan Johnson, Cayenne
Oswolf out of Traverse City, Michigan
right up there with Lesby, Alexi
Vermuing, Cole Patton, Braden Lang, and
Cam Jones.
Get up.
Racing has started to come to a little
bit more of an agreement. And you can
see basically the what these integration
groups have done here is put forth a lot
of effort and let some of the other
folks do the damage and the work here
right now. All right guys, here we are
at the base of Fire Tower right now.
Melissa Robins leading the climb,
leading this group up the climb. This
would be the highest point of the race.
We're about 25 26 miles in right now. We
had a lead group of 11. It was all come
back together. Followed up right here at
the bottom. Jenna Reinhardt bringing up
the rear. And this was a crucial section
of the race because essentially they
came off of nice gravel flowy roads onto
a less maintained road. So position is
crucial going into this climb.
Here we are. Mile 31. We have Melissa
Rollins off the front solo with three
chasers in Alexis Scarta, Sofhia, Visha,
and Cesaly Decker. And off the back of
that group, another group of five or six
coming in hot. Here
it is right here. Melissa solo win.
Congratulations. Oh yeah.
Enough time. Victory salute. And now it
is the waiting game to see who's going
to win out of the sprint between Alexis
Garda, Sophia Vishafany, and Cesley
Decker.
All right, guys. We're here with our
winner Melissa Rollins live giant team.
You just got hugged by your teammate
PETA. Like talk about what today means
and what this win means.
>> Yeah. So much. I mean I mean coming off
of Leadville, I was super stoked about
my result, but I really I really wanted
to win there. And I think just coming
off of that, I was super motivated to
go. And yeah, I mean, we've had such a
fun time up here in the Northwoods with
the Live Giant team. when we have a
house on a lake. I mean, everyone does,
but like we've been having fun and it's
such a good team environment and I just
feel like yeah, it it feels really nice
to have such an awesome team around me
and I feel like this win wasn't just for
me, but it was for the whole team.
>> Fire Tower Hill. It's steep. It's rocky.
After that, a sick downhill to the Seven
Sisters. Punchy, grassy, and on to mile
29.
Wheels are clipping right around this
corner
led by Cam and
Keegan sitting right there with Simone
Polo, Matt Beers. All right, we're so
close to the finish and last year's
sprint finish was the same thing that's
shaping up today except Alexi has got a
little bit of a gap over Beers and Kayen
Olen tight there with Lesby, Matthew
Wilson, Cole Patton still in this group
again this year. Keegan Swinson not
letting anybody go as they head to the
sprint for the finish.
Taking it. Alexi Vermuion snuck out in
front. Alexi tucked on in, taking
second. Check it out. Johnson Torbjorn,
Alexi, a tactical race today. You came
through at the finish line where you
planned and wanted to be all day long.
What happened in that last mile? Where
did you make your move and how come it
stuck? Um I I don't actually remember. I
started trying probably 7 miles to go
and you can see the group was
splintering but guys were chasing but
you always know that rubber band's going
to snap when there start to have some
gaps opening. So I kind of just bided my
time. I could tell that anybody who got
on my wheel wasn't really willing to
work. It's such a such a long way to the
finish. I mean, to be honest, I didn't
think anyone could go solo. Um, but in
the end, just kind of trusted myself,
saw the gap happen, and committed. I
mean, it's one of those times that once
you commit, you just have to believe in
yourself, cuz once the group comes back,
they're going to beat you in the sprint.
>> And for our final race results today
here at the Schwamigan 40, Melissa
Rollins bringing home the solo win.
Hands up in the air, followed by a
sprint finish with Sophia Vishafany in
second place. Alexis Scarter rounding
out third place, Cesley Decker fourth,
and Aaron Osborne in fifth place. And
let's also mention Ruth Pul who is
leading our U23 women's division right
there in 10th place. And today's results
in the Schwamigan 40. Alexi Vermuan on
the top step with a gap over the chasing
sprint group behind him with Kayen
Olshov a local out of Traverse City,
Michigan in second place just 8 seconds
behind with the big group of Brendan
Johnson, Torbjorn Road in fourth. Kobe
Freeburn rounding out the top five and
then Braden Lang, Simone Po, Cam Jones,
Pacin McKelvin, and Lesby right there 10
seconds behind. Let's take a look at our
women's lifetime Grand Prix standings
after the Schwamagan 40 mountain bike
race. Sophia Vishafany moving into first
place, knocking Cesley Decker down to
second place. Melissa Rollins having
third place right now. Alexis Scarta
moving up into fourth place. And
rounding out the top five, Cecil Leune
continues to hold on to her fifth place
And now we take a look at the men's
standings after the Schwamagan 40
mountain bike race. Not much has changed
out of that top three. Still the same
positioning for Keegan Swinson taking
that first spot. Closely followed by
Simone Pillow followed by Torbin Ru. And
in fourth place, Alexi now moves up in
position there, followed by Cam Jones,
rounding out the top five. Thanks
everyone for following along the
Schwamagan 40 mountain bike race. We
look forward to seeing you in a couple
of weeks in Bentonville for Little Sugar
and Big Sugar to round out the Lifetime
Grand Prix. For Nat Ross, I'm Lauren
Hall, and we look forward to seeing you
in a couple of weeks.

videos.title: 2024 Life Time Chequamegon MTB Festival presented by Trek | RACE HIGHLIGHTS
videos.description:
Watch the extended highlights of the 2024 Life Time Chequamegon MTB Festival presented by Trek, stop #4 of the Life Time Grand Prix presented by Mazda. The historic race, set in the scenic Northwoods of Wisconsin, sees race favorites Keegan Swenson and Sofia Gomez VillafaÃ±e battle it out against top contenders like Payson McElveen, Sean Fincham, Alex Wild, Savilia Blunk, Madigan Munro, and Alexis Skarda. Joining them are thousands of amateur riders racing through the rolling and fast-paced 40 Mile Chequamegon course, all vying for glory in one of the most beloved and competitive events of the season. 

Learn more about the Life Time Grand Prix: https://www.lifetimegrandprix.com

Learn more about the Chequamegon MTB Festival: https://www.cheqmtb.com

On-screen rider data and production crew tracking devices, Garmin Tread Baja Edition and Garmin InReach Mini 2, courtesy of Garmin.

A film by ðŸŽ¥  Cold Collaborative

Executive Producers: Kimo Seymour & Michelle Duffy Smith

Directed by Shannon Vandivier 

Producers:
Zoe Andrikidis
Ryan Cross
Bowen Parrish
Rebekah Sands
Tim Johnson
Mason Mohn

Field Producer:
Katie Rose Gurkin

Edited by Blake Campbell

Additional Edit: Tyler Domingue

Commentary Team:
Bill Elliston
Lauren Hall
Tim Johnson

Be sure to Subscribe  @LifeTimeGrandPrix  Don't miss the action!

LTGP Athlete bios and more: https://www.lifetimegrandprix.com/ath... 

Don't forget to build your Fantasy Team: https://www.fantasizr.com/sport/fantaâ€¦

videos.title: Fire Tower Hill, Chequamegon Mountain Bike Race
videos.description:
Fire Tower Hill is the toughest hill during the Chequamegon Mountain Bike Race from Hayward to Cable, WI.  This race is an icon of mountain biking in Wisconsin, and in mountain bike racing in general as it's been going strong for over 35 years.  This race doesn't have any mountains to climb, but it is a relentless 40 miles of roller after roller after roller, with lots of rough, rocky, and washed out ATV and snowmobile trails mixed in.  There are a few gravel road sections to get your heart rate down, catch your breath, and grab a snack, but otherwise you're full gas all day.  

https://www.cheqmtb.com/

https://www.strava.com/segments/762471

#bike #bikelife #bikelover #cycling #bikeride #mtb #mtblife #mtblove #mtbtrails #mtbrace #bikerace #mountainbike #mountainbikeracing #lifetime #lifetimefitness #lifetimegrandprix #ltgp #hillclimb #wisconsin #bikewisconsin #mtbwisconsin #midwestmtb #bikefestival #chequamegon40 #chequamegonfattirefestival #fattire #gopro #drone #dronevideo #hoverair #hoverairx1pro #trekbikes #yeticycles #specialized #giantbikes #canyonbikes #santacruz #santacruzbikes #alliedbikes #orangseal #wisconsin #discoverwisconsin #onlyinwisconsin
#northwoods #northwoodswisconsin #upnorth #ridebikes #biketrail #ride

videos.curation_reason: Detailed course preview of the most challenging climb with specific elevation and gradient data from a rider's perspective.

videos.title: 2023 Chequamegon 40 | Vlog
videos.description:
The 5th round of the Lifetime GP stops in Cable, Wi for the 40th edition of the Chequamegon 40. A 40 mile point to point mtb race that starts in Hayward, Wi and takes xc ski trail and single track to Cable, Wi. 

We got some rain the day before so there was a big ? on what the course was going to be like especially after last years mud fest. 

I opted to put drop bars on my Kona Hei Hei and tried to hide in the group as much as possible. 

The race was fast from the gun and super tactical with positioning being very important all day. I got gapped over the top of fire tower climb, clawed my way back on then got popped for good soloing in for 23. 

These videos take a lot of  time to make and sometimes the adventures are expensive. If you feel like donating to encourage/help me offset costs, THANKYOU! Your contribution is greatly appreciated and gives me the resources to provide y'all more content. 
Venmo: www.venmo.com/u/Kerry-Werner-1
paypal: https://www.paypal.com/paypalme/kerrywerner

https://bike.shimano.com/en-US/home.html
https://www.konaworld.com
https://www.maxxis.com/tires/bicycle

Corral oh hey good luck everyone
woo crush it hey
thanks that was easy now got to get to
the Finish but first a bowl of
cereal
that's the shuttle
bus I got 20 minutes to throw a kit on
and get on it so I'm going to leave the
camera here see you guys on the start
line
let
w
23 whatever
right go
here I can
have oh we're right there
dude all right Potter it was real thanks
for the ride homie have a safe drive
back to
colorat know when you get
there see
you and we are headed back to Rowan Oak
on my way to the gate not super pumped
with how yesterday went but not super
bummed about it either it was just like
really wanted to be in that that big
bunch Sprint of 14 that seemed like a
lot of fun but way 8 miles to go over
the top of fire tower climb I was able
to kind of cut my losses and I came off
the back there but then got back on on
the other
side uh but then we hit some Punchy
stuff that was really
sloggy and
yeah I came off I couldn't do it so I

some of the people that started in front

videos.curation_reason: Excellent first-person race vlog showing pre-race prep, course preview, and personal experience from a pro rider's perspective.

videos.title: On the Attack | Ep 4: Gap to Glory
videos.description:
In Episode 4 of On the Attack, we dive into the menâ€™s race at the Life Time Chequamegon MTB Festival â€” stop #4 of the Life Time Grand Prix. It was a race defined by razor-thin margins, as race leaders clung to a narrow gap from Hayward to Cable, holding off a charging field in one of the tightest battles of the season.

From Grand Prix veterans to challengers fighting for every second, hear directly from the men who pushed the pace, bridged the gaps, and delivered a finish for the ages in Chequamegon.

Learn more about the Life Time Grand Prix: lifetimegrandprix.com
Learn more about the Chequamegon MTB Festival: cheqmtb.com
videos.transcript:
Schwamian, it's like a 2hour long short
track cross country race. Big pack
racing, super aggressive, always
battling for position.
We are in Schwamagan, Wisconsin.
This is the 42nd edition Schwamagan Fat
Tire Festival. This is going to be one
fast mountain bike race in front of us
today. You know, you can try and put a
lot into Swarmingham, but like we're all
fit riders, but then you throw something
like this in, it's really exciting. It's
really like interesting to see how
different riders are going to like fare
in this in this kind of race.
>> I don't know exactly what to expect. Uh
I've been traveling a lot. I hope I
brought my legs with me from China.
>> The thing to keep an eye on on this
course is pinch points and of course
there's the fire tower climb. I mean,
you really got to keep your head up and
you really got to be good at riding in
the pack. Well,
>> we go from racing at super high
elevation at Leadville,
and then a month later, we have to tune
our engines to sea level race, really
short and punchy, completely different
race demands, a lot more short sprint
workouts, just trying to get some
high-end power.
I think Schwamagan is one of the hardest
races in the Grand Prix to win.
you get one shot and you got to back
yourself and believe in yourself. And so
every time you see someone win here, if
it's not in the sprint, they completely
backed themselves on some random little
climb and held on for dear life.
[Music]
Since a couple years ago, we start
straight up a hill, which just makes
everybody wonder what's coming.
>> There's a lot of energy. It's the one
race where we take off full gas from the
start. And I love starts like that where
no one's talking. We're just like locked
in and ready to go. Just make sure you
clip in, start pedaling, and then kind
of fight for position as you get over
the first climb.
>> Yeah, the start of Schwamagan was uh
less than perfect. missed my pedal three
times, but uh that's that's how racing
goes.
>> They are humming up this hill making it
look absolutely easy.
>> Cam Jones actually went out front off
the start.
He was obviously willing to go to that
level and then there's like the rest of
us who are willing to go to like, you
know, what felt kind of reasonable. It
was kind of a a cat and mouse game for
the first 15 minutes. And once you
settle in, I think that's when the true
racing starts cuz before that it's a lot
of uh just mental stress.
The race was really just on um from the
beginning to the end.
It was just kind of people trying to
make their moves, others chasing it
down. Then I think a lot of people kind
of looked to Matt and to Keegan to kind
of get the race back under control,
which I think is frustrating for them. I
guess for me, I was just kind of like
trying to ride good position.
Schwarmagan is like a big washing
machine. You know, it's constantly
riders moving up on the side and
drifting back. there. You know, we have
a really wide grass field, but the
reality is one racing line. You
constantly have to be moving forward,
otherwise you're moving backwards. Um,
and I think there's something that comes
from the road that helps me with that.
And it's all a chess match and uh the
winner is uh always right at this race
and it changes every year.
It's the long season in the Lifetime
Grand Prix and this is a very
challenging event. Schwamagan is no test
of anything but skills, power,
determination.
So we have 16 in that lead group at this
point. Still sizable, but that was the
early animation from Simone, from
Keegan, from Matt Beers.
>> Yeah, it kind of stayed together. There
was some surging, but like I say,
everyone can kind of hang on for that,
you know, grit their teeth and hang on
for 10 or 20 seconds and and make it
over this the crest of the climb and
then it sort of like sits up again. And
fire tower is always like a big
selective point on this course. It's
kind of the only steep climb.
The fight in the fire tower I feel like
is kind of changing a little bit. Um,
every year it definitely is hard, but we
used to kind of see that as a big split
in the race. I don't I think everyone's
just strong now. The depth in the Grand
Prix is growing a lot.
>> Come on. Come on. You got this. Go.
Let's go. Go, go, go, go, go.
>> It solidified our lead group of 15 or 20
riders, but um, nobody broke away. We
all kind of stayed together.
I think from fire tower on toward the
finish. Uh you kind of get on the dirt
road for a second and then you kind of
get back off onto what we call seven
sisters, seven big climbs. Um kind of
roll over this grass field and Keegan
was hitting it pretty hard. I was really
hoping that uh we would kind of break
into a smaller group on those rollers.
But um since the speed's so high, the
draft is so good, and um so many people
came into the end, I was thinking, "Oh,
this is not the plan."
Probably sevenish miles to go. I started
kind of feeling people out. Um I
attacked on one roller and uh Matt and
Cayenne came with me. Um but they
wouldn't really commit. Did it again.
They both same guys came with me again.
And then I saw Matt chasing and I was
like, "Okay, well like this, you guys
still aren't committing." and um kind of
held back for a second and then four
miles to go just on one of the last big
steep rollers. I just came over the top
of a couple guys and I was like, "Well,
now's the time to commit. Looked back
once, had a gap, and I was like probably
10 to 12 minutes from the finish line
here and I know what I can do." And so I
just kind of hit it as hard as I could,
focused on speed.
That point you there's no reason to look
back. Race is coming behind you. I knew
exactly what what I had to do. Uh the
question is always just you know how how
fast is the group and what are they
going to do working together. Yeah. So I
went uh in these last rollers in the
different finish. Uh there was a young
guy out in between Alexi and the group.
I went across to him um from the group
and then he and I just I mean I knew
that that was second place in the Grand
Prix. So I was willing to just bury it
and stay out in front of the group.
And yeah, I just thought, you know,
everyone was kind of looking to Matt and
Keegan and I was just like, I'm going to
go go around them and try. Um, it's time
to try something. I think I think that
was maybe where we made the mistake was
just letting letting those moves go and
then um hesitating and the group swelled
up and then it came down to just this
massive group for the for the final
sprint.
>> Here we go. Here we go. Give some room,
ladies and gentlemen. Here we go. down
to the final stretch right there off the
front. Alexi Bel
your 2025
Schwaban
champion
the Michigan boy makes it stick. What
a dust storm of adrenaline and
excitement.
What a finish.
It was pretty great. I was probably the
most smoked I've been at a Schwamagan
win. Um, couldn't even get two hands off
the bars. Afraid I was going to crash.
But yeah, I mean, the feeling of winning
solo is something that I is really hard
to describe. There's that one moment
right before the finish line where you
feel it.
>> You did it, buddy.
>> I hated the last 1.8 miles.
>> It's just so emotional, right? You back
yourself. It's very, very quick in that,
you know, that one second you have to
yourself before you cross.
>> I'm stoked. Like I was in a bit of a
hole after Leadville just like mentally.
So to come back and like consolidate
which is like what I wanted to do at
Leadville. I'm not sure where I'll end
up once we drop Leadville. But yeah,
Little Sugar will be a fun race. It's
really cool to come to the Northwoods
here in Wisconsin. Um this is like a
really warm welcome to fall.
>> I think one of the things I love about
the race is all the camaraderie that
comes out between the guys.
There's a lot of stress around a lot of
races, but this is one that I think
people, you know, for the most part are
excited to race together. And I I really
enjoy that.
videos.curation_reason: Behind-the-scenes race analysis with direct quotes from pro athletes describing the tactical nature and unique challenges of the race.

quotes.text: Fire Tower Hill is probably the hardest hill on the whole course. It's about 220 ft elevation gain over 4/10 of a mile with a middle section about 17% and at the very top we get up to 21%. Every time I've done it during the Schwamian race, I've had to walk.

Schwamagan is like a 2-hour long short track cross country race. Big pack racing, super aggressive, always battling for position. It's like a big washing machine - constantly riders moving up on the side and drifting back.

This is the Burk ski course without snow on it, this is why I'm putting drop bars on this beast. It's one race where we take off full gas from the start and you got to back yourself and believe in yourself.
